title: Chinese Government provides a grant for the provision of urea fertilizer in 2007
description: On January 11, 2007, China's Ministry of Commerce studied bidding methods to find a potential implementer of China's urea fertilizer donation to North Korea. Furthermore, the Ministry of Commerce's Tender Committee invited 9 companies to participate in the bidding.
staff_comments: 1. The date of agreement, completion, and transaction amount of the project are all unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides a grant for the provision of urea fertilizer in 2007

# Description
On January 11, 2007, China's Ministry of Commerce studied bidding methods to find a potential implementer of China's urea fertilizer donation to North Korea. Furthermore, the Ministry of Commerce's Tender Committee invited 9 companies to participate in the bidding.
justification: Project involves donation of agricultural inputs without clear environmental impact or energy transition implications
evidence: Urea fertilizer donation, agricultural sector focus, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government agrees to provide 50,000 tons of fuel oil in exchange for North Korea shutting down its nuclear facilities in 2007
description: On February 13, 2007, the North Korean Government agreed to close its main nuclear reactor in exchange for a package of food, fuel and other aid from the United States, China, South Korea, and Russia. Under the agreement, the first part of the aid — 50,000 tons of fuel oil, or an equivalent value of economic or humanitarian aid — was to be provided by the United States, China, South Korea, and Russia. Although the accord set a 60-day deadline for North Korea to accomplish its first steps toward disarmament, it did not define a time or a negotiation for the actual removal of North Korea’s nuclear weapons and the fuel manufactured to produce them. In total, the donor delegations agreed to donate 1 million tons of fuel oil to North Korea: after delivering the first 50,000 tons during an initial 60-day period, the remainder of the aid was to be delivered when North Korea met later requirements to disclose and disable its nuclear arsenal. Later in 2007, North Korea received 50,000 tons of fuel from South Korea while it carried out the first phase of the agreement -- halting operations at its Yongbyon nuclear complex under monitoring by the International Atomic Energy Agency. Upon completion of the second phase of the deal, which called for Pyongyang to fully declare and disable its nuclear program, the Chinese Government agreed to provide 50,000 tons of fuel oil to North Korea in mid-August 2007. However, it is unclear if this full oil package was delivered by the Chinese Government.   50,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 365,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($26,404,100), AidData takes the average price ($72.34) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) Crude Oil in 2007 and multiplies it by 365,000 barrels of oil.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government agrees to provide 50,000 tons of fuel oil in exchange for North Korea shutting down its nuclear facilities in 2007

# Description
On February 13, 2007, the North Korean Government agreed to close its main nuclear reactor in exchange for a package of food, fuel and other aid from the United States, China, South Korea, and Russia. Under the agreement, the first part of the aid — 50,000 tons of fuel oil, or an equivalent value of economic or humanitarian aid — was to be provided by the United States, China, South Korea, and Russia. Although the accord set a 60-day deadline for North Korea to accomplish its first steps toward disarmament, it did not define a time or a negotiation for the actual removal of North Korea’s nuclear weapons and the fuel manufactured to produce them. In total, the donor delegations agreed to donate 1 million tons of fuel oil to North Korea: after delivering the first 50,000 tons during an initial 60-day period, the remainder of the aid was to be delivered when North Korea met later requirements to disclose and disable its nuclear arsenal. Later in 2007, North Korea received 50,000 tons of fuel from South Korea while it carried out the first phase of the agreement -- halting operations at its Yongbyon nuclear complex under monitoring by the International Atomic Energy Agency. Upon completion of the second phase of the deal, which called for Pyongyang to fully declare and disable its nuclear program, the Chinese Government agreed to provide 50,000 tons of fuel oil to North Korea in mid-August 2007. However, it is unclear if this full oil package was delivered by the Chinese Government.   50,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 365,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($26,404,100), AidData takes the average price ($72.34) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) Crude Oil in 2007 and multiplies it by 365,000 barrels of oil.
justification: Project involves provision of fuel oil, a fossil fuel product, as part of a diplomatic agreement
evidence: 50,000 tons of fuel oil provided to North Korea, equivalent to 365,000 barrels of oil

title: China Donates Medical Supplies for Emergent Flood Relief
description: On August 30, 2007, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Liu Jianchao announced that the Chinese government will provide humanitarian assistance to North Korea that has suffered from floods. After continuous heavy rains caused severe flooding in North Korea in early August, 2007, China donated medicine and medical equipments in two batches for emergent flood relief. The delivery of both batches of supplies are said to be completed by 27 September, 2007.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China Donates Medical Supplies for Emergent Flood Relief

# Description
On August 30, 2007, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Liu Jianchao announced that the Chinese government will provide humanitarian assistance to North Korea that has suffered from floods. After continuous heavy rains caused severe flooding in North Korea in early August, 2007, China donated medicine and medical equipments in two batches for emergent flood relief. The delivery of both batches of supplies are said to be completed by 27 September, 2007.
justification: Project involves humanitarian aid for flood relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medicine and medical equipment for flood relief, humanitarian assistance focus

title: Chinese Government donates spare parts worth RMB 40 million for O&M of Pyongyang Metro and 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant in 2007
description: In 2007, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) agreed to provide an RMB 40 million grant to the North Korean Government for the provision of spare parts to support the operations and maintenance (O&M) of the Pyongyang Metro and the 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant. China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corp. Ltd. (COMPLANT or 中成进出口股份有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. AidData assumes that this project was completed since a follow-on project was approved in 2008 (as captured via Project ID#73835). However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unknown.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 年度向朝鲜提供零配件项目.2. The Pyongyang Metro was the first modern urban rail project built with Chinese aid. It was completed in 1975. 3. This is an O&M project supported via recurring grants from MOFCOM between 2001 and 2008. However, AidData was not able to identify any further evidence of financial support from MOFCOM after 2008. As such, no additional MOFCOM grants are recorded after 2008.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title

China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corp. Ltd. (COMPLANT or 中成进出口股份有限公司) was the contractor responsible for implementation. AidData assumes that this project was completed since a follow-on project was approved in 2008 (as captured via Project ID#73835). However, precise project implementation start and end dates are unknown.
justification: Primary focus is supporting operations of a large coal-fired power plant, which directly contributes to fossil fuel dependency
evidence: 1600MW Pukchang Coal-Fired Power Plant, provision of spare parts for O&M

title: Chinese Government donates 53,688 metric tons of maize in 2007
description: According to Chinese Government reporting to the World Food Program’s International Food Aid Information System (INTERFAIS), the Chinese Government donated and delivered 53,688 metric tons of maize (in 11 separate deliveries of 550 tons, 1710 tons, 1000 tons, 3780 tons, 2485 tons, 5174 tons, 3284 tons, 6346 tons, 5706 tons, 14588 tons, and 9065 tons) to North Korea in 2007.  To estimate the monetary value of the maize donation ($8,867,110.08), AidData takes the international price of a ton of maize in January 2007 ($165.16) and multiplies it by 53,688 tons.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title

# Description

To estimate the monetary value of the maize donation ($8,867,110.08), AidData takes the international price of a ton of maize in January 2007 ($165.16) and multiplies it by 53,688 tons.
justification: Food aid project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Maize donation for food security assistance, humanitarian focus

title: Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2007
description: In 2007, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($265,126,100), AidData has taken the average price ($72.34) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2007 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
staff_comments: 1. In 2012, a North Korean source disclosed that every year ‘the Ministry of Commerce of China and the North Korean government will discuss the catalogue of aid products, quantity, period, etc., but it is basically 100,000 tons of grain, 500,000 tons of oil, and materials needed by North Korea worth 20 million US dollars.’  This annual oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government dates back to the 1970s. On October 17, 1970, the Chinese Government and the Government of North Korea signed an Agreement on Mutual Supply of Critical Materials 1971-1976. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the North Korean Government with 500,000 tons of crude oil per year.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2007

# Description
In 2007, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($265,126,100), AidData has taken the average price ($72.34) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2007 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
justification: The project involves the donation and transportation of crude oil, a fossil fuel, which contributes to fossil fuel dependency and has negative environmental impacts
evidence: 500,000 tons of crude oil donation, Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline for oil transportation, processing at Ponghwa Chemical Factory

title: Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology donates computers, office equipment, and scientific and technological books and magazines to North Korea's National Academy of Sciences
description: On December 13, 2007, the 42nd meeting of the China-DPRK Federation of Science and Technology Cooperation Committee was held in Pyongyang. Both sides signed a protocol related to strengthening scientific and technological cooperation. At the same time, the Ministry of Science and Technology of China decided to send computers, corresponding office equipment, and scientific and technological books and magazines to the National Academy of Sciences of Korea.
